865    /**
866     * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
867     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
868     * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
869     */
870    public static float alpha(final float encoded)
871    {
872        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 25) / 127f;
873    }
874
875
876    /**
877     * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given HSLuv color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
878     * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
879     * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
880     * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
881     * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
882     * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
883     * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
884     * 0 chroma, and the most colorful value (a shade of purple) should have ??? chroma.
885     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
886     * @return a float between 0.0f and ??? that represents how colorful the given value is
887     */
888    public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
889        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
890        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
891        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
892        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
893
894        // HSLuv to Lch
895        if (L > 0.99999f) {
896            return 0f;
897        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
898            return 0f;
899        } else
900            return chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
901    }
902    /**
903     * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (exact) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
904     * combination, using HSLuv's versions of lightness and hue (not raw HSL). This is useful to know the bounds of
905     * {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater than 1.0f . Note that this version of chromaLimit() is
906     * a little slower than Oklab's version, because this has to go to greater lengths to become accurate.
907     * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
908     * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
909     * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 1.0f
910     */
911    public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness) {
912        final float h = hue - MathUtils.floor(hue);
913        float sin = TrigTools.sinTurns(h);
914        float cos = TrigTools.cosTurns(h);
915        float sub1 = (lightness + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
916        sub1 *= sub1 * sub1;
917        float sub2 = sub1 > epsilon ? sub1 : lightness / kappa;
918        float min = Float.MAX_VALUE;
919        for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
920            float m1 = m[i][0] * sub2, m2 = m[i][1] * sub2, m3 = m[i][2] * sub2;
921            for (int t = 0; t < 2; t++) {
922                m2 -= t;
923                float top1 = 2845.17f * m1 - 948.39f * m3;
924                float top2 = (8384.22f * m3 + 7698.60f * m2 + 7317.18f * m1) * lightness;
925                float bottom = (6322.60f * m3 - 1264.52f * m2);
926                float length = intersectLength(sin, cos, top1 / bottom, top2 / bottom);
927                if (length >= 0) min = Math.min(min, length);
928            }
929        }
930        return min;
931    }
932
933    private static float intersectLength (float sin, float cos, float line1, float line2) {
934        return line2 / (sin - line1 * cos);
935    }
936
937    /**
938     * Gets the color with the same L as the HSLuv color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
939     * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
940     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
941     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format; does not need to be in-gamut
942     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
943     * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
944     */
945    public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
946        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) | 0x0000FF00);
947    }
948    /**
949     * Gets the color with the given H, L, and alpha, but ignores the given S and instead uses the furthest S
950     * from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
951     * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
952     * @param H hue component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
953     * @param S saturation; ignored, and will always be maximized
954     * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
955     * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
956     * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the H and L of packed
957     */
958    public static float maximizeSaturation(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
959        return clamp(H, 1f, L, alpha);
960    }
961
962    /**
963     * Gets the hue of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands hue rather than how HSL does.
964     * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
965     * and 1 (exclusive).
966     * <br>
967     * This is the same as {@link #channelH(float)}.
968     *
969     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
970     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the HSLuv color space
971     */
972    public static float hsluvHue(final float packed) {
973        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
974    }
975
976    /**
977     * Gets the saturation of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands saturation rather than how HSL
978     * does. Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue
979     * and lightness, and is between 0 and 1. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
980     * <br>
981     * This is the same as {@link #channelS(float)}.
982     *
983     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
984     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the HSLuv color space
985     */
986    public static float hsluvSaturation(final float packed) {
987        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
988    }
989    /**
990     * Gets the lightness of the given HSLuv float color, but as HSLuv understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
991     * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
992     * and 1 (inclusive).
993     * <br>
994     * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
995     *
996     * @param packed a packed HSLuv float color
997     * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the HSLuv color space
998     */
999    public static float hsluvLightness(final float packed){
1000        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f;
1001    }
1002
1003    /**
1004     * A different way to specify a HSLuv color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1005     * color but calculating them directly in the HSLuv color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1006     * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma.
1007     * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1008     * like {@code lightness} and the method {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the
1009     * lightness should be equivalent to {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same
1010     * chroma and lightness, but different hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or
1011     * both chroma values exceeded the gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If
1012     * a chroma value given is greater than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use
1013     * {@link #hsluvHue(float)}, {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #hsluvLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and
1014     * lightness values from an existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1015     * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1016     * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1017     * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1018     * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1019     * @return a packed HSLuv float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1020     */
1021    public static float hsluvByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1022        hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
1023        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1024        if(lightness <= 0f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 0f, alpha);
1025        if(lightness >= 1f) return hsluv(hue, 0f, 1f, alpha);
1026        return hsluv(hue, Math.max(chroma, 0f) / (chromaLimit(hue, lightness) + 0.0001f), lightness, alpha);
1027    }
1028
1029    /**
1030     * Gets a color as a HSLuv packed float given floats representing HSL hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
1031     * You should usually prefer just using {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)} to get colors with these values.
1032     * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
1033     * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
1034     * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
1035     * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
1036     * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
1037     * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
1038     * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
1039     *
1040     * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
1041     * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
1042     * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
1043     * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
1044     * @return a HSLuv float encoding a color with the given properties
1045     */
1046    public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
1047        if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
1048            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
1049        } else if (lightness >= 0.999f) {
1050            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x00FF0000);
1051        } else {
1052            return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
1053        }
1054    }
1055
1056    /**
1057     * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
1058     * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details.
1059     *
1060     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1061     * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
1062     */
1063    public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
1064        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1065        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1066        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1067        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1068
1069        // HSLuv to Lch
1070        float C;
1071        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1072            L = 1;
1073            C = 0;
1074        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1075            L = 0;
1076            C = 0;
1077        } else
1078            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1079
1080        // Lch to Luv
1081        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1082        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1083
1084        // Luv to XYZ
1085        float x, y, z;
1086        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1087            x = 0;
1088            y = 0;
1089            z = 0;
1090        } else {
1091            if (L <= 0.08f)
1092                y = L / kappa;
1093            else {
1094                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1095                y *= y * y;
1096            }
1097            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1098            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1099            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1100            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1101            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1102        }
1103        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1104        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1105        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1106        float X, Y, W;
1107        if(g < b) {
1108            X = b;
1109            Y = g;
1110        }
1111        else {
1112            X = g;
1113            Y = b;
1114        }
1115        if(r < X) {
1116            W = r;
1117        }
1118        else {
1119            W = X;
1120            X = r;
1121        }
1122        return X - Math.min(W, Y);
1123    }
1124
1125    /**
1126     * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for HSLuv. This
1127     * ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f (white).
1128     *
1129     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1130     * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
1131     */
1132    public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
1133        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1134        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1135        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1136        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1137
1138        // HSLuv to Lch
1139        float C;
1140        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1141            L = 1;
1142            C = 0;
1143        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1144            L = 0;
1145            C = 0;
1146        } else
1147            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1148
1149        // Lch to Luv
1150        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1151        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1152
1153        // Luv to XYZ
1154        float x, y, z;
1155        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1156            x = 0;
1157            y = 0;
1158            z = 0;
1159        } else {
1160            if (L <= 0.08f)
1161                y = L / kappa;
1162            else {
1163                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1164                y *= y * y;
1165            }
1166            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1167            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1168            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1169            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1170            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1171        }
1172        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1173        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1174        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1175        float X, Y, W;
1176        if(g < b) {
1177            X = b;
1178            Y = g;
1179        }
1180        else {
1181            X = g;
1182            Y = b;
1183        }
1184        if(r < X) {
1185            W = r;
1186        }
1187        else {
1188            W = X;
1189            X = r;
1190        }
1191        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1192        return X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1193    }
1194
1195    /**
1196     * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
1197     * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
1198     *
1199     * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1200     * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
1201     * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
1202     */
1203    public static float hue(final float encoded) {
1204        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1205        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1206        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1207        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1208
1209        // HSLuv to Lch
1210        float C;
1211        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1212            L = 1;
1213            C = 0;
1214        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1215            L = 0;
1216            C = 0;
1217        } else
1218            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1219
1220        // Lch to Luv
1221        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1222        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1223
1224        // Luv to XYZ
1225        float x, y, z;
1226        if (L < 0.00001f) {
1227            x = 0;
1228            y = 0;
1229            z = 0;
1230        } else {
1231            if (L <= 0.08f)
1232                y = L / kappa;
1233            else {
1234                y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1235                y *= y * y;
1236            }
1237            float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1238            float varU = U * iL + refU;
1239            float varV = V * iL + refV;
1240            x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1241            z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1242        }
1243        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1244        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1245        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1246        float X, Y, Z, W;
1247        if(g < b) {
1248            X = b;
1249            Y = g;
1250            Z = -1f;
1251            W = 2f / 3f;
1252        }
1253        else {
1254            X = g;
1255            Y = b;
1256            Z = 0f;
1257            W = -1f / 3f;
1258        }
1259        if(r < X) {
1260            Z = W;
1261            W = r;
1262        }
1263        else {
1264            W = X;
1265            X = r;
1266        }
1267        float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1268        return Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
1269    }
1270    /**
1271     * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
1272     * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not HSLuv! Takes
1273     * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
1274     * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
1275     * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
1276     * result of {@code basis} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
1277     * This won't allocate any objects.
1278     * <br>
1279     * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
1280     * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
1281     * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
1282     * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
1283     * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
1284     *
1285     * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
1286     * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
1287     * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
1288     * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
1289     * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
1290     * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
1291     */
1292    public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
1293        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
1294        final float li = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
1295        opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 25) / 127f, 0f), 1f);
1296        if (li <= 0.001f)
1297            return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000));
1298        float H = ((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1299        float S = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f);
1300        float L = li;
1301//        float L = (1f/1.16f)*(li + 0.16f);
1302
1303        // HSLuv to Lch
1304        float C;
1305        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1306            L = 1;
1307            C = 0;
1308        } else
1309            C = chromaLimit(H, L) * S;
1310
1311        // Lch to Luv
1312        float U = TrigTools.cosTurns(H) * C;
1313        float V = TrigTools.sinTurns(H) * C;
1314
1315        // Luv to XYZ
1316        float x, y, z;
1317        if (L <= 0.08f)
1318            y = L / kappa;
1319        else {
1320            y = (L + 0.16f) / 1.16f;
1321            y *= y * y;
1322        }
1323        float iL = 1f / (13f * L);
1324        float varU = U * iL + refU;
1325        float varV = V * iL + refV;
1326        x = 9 * varU * y / (4 * varV);
1327        z = (3 * y / varV) - x / 3 - 5 * y;
1328        final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+3.2404542f * x + -1.5371385f * y + -0.4985314f * z, 0f), 1f));
1329        final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.9692660f * x + +1.8760108f * y + +0.0415560f * z, 0f), 1f));
1330        final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+0.0556434f * x + -0.2040259f * y + +1.0572252f * z, 0f), 1f));
1331        float X, Y, Z, W;
1332        if(g < b) {
1333            X = b;
1334            Y = g;
1335            Z = -1f;
1336            W = 2f / 3f;
1337        }
1338        else {
1339            X = g;
1340            Y = b;
1341            Z = 0f;
1342            W = -1f / 3f;
1343        }
1344        if(r < X) {
1345            Z = W;
1346            W = r;
1347        }
1348        else {
1349            W = X;
1350            X = r;
1351        }
1352        final float d = X - Math.min(W, Y);
1353        final float lum = X * (1f - 0.5f * d / (X + 1e-10f));
1354        hue += Math.abs(Z + (W - Y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
1355        saturation += (X - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
1356        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
1357    }
1358
1359
1360    /**
1361     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1362     * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1363     * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. H is wrapped, while S,
1364     * L, and alpha are clamped.
1365     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1366     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1367     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1368     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1369     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1370     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1371     */
1372    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha) {
1373        return editHSLuv(encoded, addH, addS, addL, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1374    }
1375    /**
1376     * Given a packed float HSLuv color, this edits its H, S, L, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel
1377     * by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping (this
1378     * wraps H instead of clamping it). This means the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has
1379     * {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value
1380     * (of course, the given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want
1381     * to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. You can multiply S by 0 to make
1382     * a grayscale color, or by a large value to make any non-grayscale color more vibrant. Multiplying H generally
1383     * isn't very useful, but adding to H can be used to do hue cycling (because H wraps).
1384     * @param encoded a packed float HSLuv color
1385     * @param addH how much to add to the H channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1386     * @param addS how much to add to the S channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1387     * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1388     * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1389     * @param mulH how much to multiply the H channel by; should be non-negative (not always)
1390     * @param mulS how much to multiply the S channel by; usually non-negative
1391     * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1392     * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1393     * @return a packed float HSLuv color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1394     */
1395    public static float editHSLuv(float encoded, float addH, float addS, float addL, float addAlpha,
1396                                  float mulH, float mulS, float mulL, float mulAlpha) {
1397        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1398        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1399        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1400        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1401        float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1402
1403        H = H * mulH + addH;
1404        H -= MathUtils.floor(H);
1405        S = Math.min(Math.max(S * mulS + addS, 0f), 1f);
1406        L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1407        alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1408        return hsluv(H, S, L, alpha);
1409    }
1410
1411    /**
1412     * The "H" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its hue; ranges from 0.0f to 1.0f .
1413     * You can edit the H of a color with {@link #rotateH(float, float)}.
1414     *
1415     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1416     * @return the H value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1417     */
1418    public static float channelH(final float encoded)
1419    {
1420        return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
1421    }
1422
1423    /**
1424     * The "S" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its saturation; ranges from 0.0f to
1425     * 1.0f . You can edit the S of a color with {@link #enrich(float, float)} and {@link #dullen(float, float)}.
1426     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1427     * @return the S value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1428     */
1429    public static float channelS(final float encoded)
1430    {
1431        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1432    }
1433
1434    /**
1435     * The "L" channel of the given packed float in HSLuv format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
1436     * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
1437     *
1438     * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1439     * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
1440     */
1441    public static float channelL(final float encoded)
1442    {
1443        return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
1444    }
1445
1446    /**
1447     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1448     * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
1449     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1450     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1451     * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1452     * saturation of start as-is.
1453     * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
1454     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1455     * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
1456     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
1457     */
1458    public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
1459        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1460        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
1461    }
1462
1463    /**
1464     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
1465     * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
1466     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1467     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1468     * towards black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha, hue, and
1469     * saturation of start as-is.
1470     * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
1471     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1472     * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
1473     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
1474     */
1475    public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
1476        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
1477        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
1478    }
1479
1480    /**
1481     * Moves the color of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating the color). While change
1482     * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
1483     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1484     * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
1485     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1486     * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
1487     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
1488     */
1489    public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
1490        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1491        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
1492    }
1493
1494    /**
1495     * Brings the color of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating the color). While
1496     * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
1497     * from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only S, and won't change hue, lightness, or alpha.
1498     * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
1499     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1500     * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
1501     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
1502     */
1503    public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
1504        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
1505        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
1506    }
1507
1508    /**
1509     * Cycles the hue of the packed float color by change. If change is 0f, this returns start as-is. If change is
1510     * positive, this rotates from red to orange to yellow to green, and so on. If change is negative, this instead
1511     * rotates from green to yellow to orange to red.  A change value is typically between -1f and 1f; if change is
1512     * exactly an integer, then this will wrap around in a perfect circle and produce no change. The start value should
1513     * be a packed color, as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations
1514     * of temporary Colors. This only changes H, and won't change saturation, lightness, or alpha.
1515     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1516     * @param change how much to rotate hue by, as a float typically between -1 and 1; further from 0 rotates more
1517     * @return a packed float that represents a color like start but with a rotated hue
1518     */
1519    public static float rotateH(final float start, final float change) {
1520        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
1521        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (256f * change)) & 0xFF) | other);
1522    }
1523
1524    /**
1525     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
1526     * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1527     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
1528     * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
1529     * towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1530     * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
1531     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1532     * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
1533     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
1534     */
1535    public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
1536        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1537        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1538    }
1539
1540    /**
1541     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
1542     * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
1543     * {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
1544     * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
1545     * lerp towards transparent. This won't change the H, S, or L of the color.
1546     * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
1547     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1548     * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
1549     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
1550     */
1551    public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
1552        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
1553        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
1554    }
1555
1556    /**
1557     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1558     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with roughly inverted lightness but the same hue, saturation, and alpha.
1559     * This won't ever produce black or other very dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for
1560     * lightness values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a
1561     * foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the
1562     * lightness unchanged if the hues of the contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different.
1563     * This has nothing to do with the contrast channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can
1564     * make too-similar lightness values further apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor}
1565     * to maximize its lightness difference from {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
1566     * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
1567     * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
1568     * @return a different HSLuv packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
1569     */
1570    public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1571    {
1572        final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
1573                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
1574                H = (bits & 0xff),
1575//                S = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1576                L = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
1577                cH = (contrastBits & 0xff),
1578//                cS = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
1579                cL = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
1580        if(Math.abs(H - cH) >= 90)
1581            return mainColor;
1582        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFE00FFFF) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 128 : 128 - L * 0.45f) << 16);
1583    }
1584
1585    /**
1586     * Given a packed float HSLuv color {@code mainColor} and another HSLuv color that it should be made to contrast
1587     * with, gets a packed float HSLuv color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
1588     * but the same hue, saturation, and opacity. This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well
1589     * as a foreground when displayed on a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
1590     * <br>
1591     * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
1592     * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant hues. Because it
1593     * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
1594     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
1595     * @param contrastingColor a packed HSLuv float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
1596     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
1597     */
1598    public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
1599    {
1600        final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
1601        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((contrast >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (main >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1602    }
1603
1604    /**
1605     * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
1606     * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
1607     * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
1608     * <br>
1609     * Calling {@code offsetLightness(mainColor)} is the same as calling
1610     * {@code ColorTools.differentiateLightness(mainColor, mainColor)}.
1611     * @param mainColor a packed HSLuv float color
1612     * @return a different packed HSLuv float color, with its L channel changed.
1613     */
1614    public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
1615        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
1616        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE00FFFF) | ((decoded >>> 16) + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded >>> 16 & 0xFF) >>> 1);
1617    }
1618
1619    /**
1620     * Makes the additive HSLuv color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
1621     * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
1622     * returns {@code Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
1623     * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery. This only
1624     * affects the saturation and lightness of the color; its hue and alpha are unchanged.
1625     * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
1626     * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
1627     * @return a HSLuv float color between gray and {@code color}
1628     */
1629    public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
1630        final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
1631                sS = 0x80, sL = 0x80,
1632                eH = (e & 0xFF), eS = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eL = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1633        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(eH
1634                | (((int) (sS + fraction * (eS - sS)) & 0xFF) << 8)
1635                | (((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF) << 16)
1636                | (eAlpha << 24));
1637    }
1638
1639    /**
1640     * Returns true always; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1641     * @param packed a packed float color as HSLuv
1642     * @return true
1643     */
1644    public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1645    {
1646        return true;
1647    }
1648
1649    /**
1650     * Returns true if S and L are each between 0 and 1; if valid, HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1651     * @param H hue, as an unbounded float
1652     * @param S saturation, as a float from 0 to 1
1653     * @param L lightness, as a float from 0 to 1
1654     * @return true if S and L are both between 0 and 1
1655     */
1656    public static boolean inGamut(float H, float S, float L)
1657    {
1658        return (S >= 0f && S <= 1.0f && L >= 0f && L <= 1.0f);
1659    }
1660
1661    /**
1662     * Returns its argument unchanged; HSLuv colors are always in-gamut.
1663     * @param packed a packed float color in HSLuv format
1664     * @return {@code packed}, unchanged
1665     */
1666    public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1667        return packed;
1668    }
1669
1670    /**
1671     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1672     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1673     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1674     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1675     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1676     */
1677    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L) {
1678        return clamp(H - MathUtils.floor(H), S, L, 1f);
1679    }
1680    /**
1681     * Identical to calling {@link #clamp(float, float, float, float)} with 1f as its last parameter.
1682     * @param H hue; will be wrapped between 0 and 1
1683     * @param S saturation; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1684     * @param L lightness; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1685     * @param alpha opacity; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1686     * @return an HSLuv color with the specified channel values, wrapped or clamped as appropriate
1687     */
1688    public static float limitToGamut(float H, float S, float L, float alpha) {
1689        return clamp(H, S, L, alpha);
1690    }
1691
1692    /**
1693     * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1694     * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1695     * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1696     * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1697     * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the H, S, and L of the
1698     * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1699     * isn't greater than the variance.
1700     * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}
1701     * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1702     * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1703     * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1704     */
1705    public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1706        final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1707        float H = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1708        float S = (decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) / 255f;
1709        float L = reverseLight((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) / 255f);
1710        final float limit = variance * variance;
1711        float dist, x, y, z;
1712        for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1713            x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1714            y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1715            z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1716            seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1717            dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1718            if(dist <= limit)
1719                return clamp(H + x, S + y, L + z, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
1720        }
1721        return color;
1722    }
1723
1724    /**
1725     * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut and should be uniformly distributed.
1726     * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1727     * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1728     */
1729    public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1730        return hsluv(random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), random.nextFloat(), 1f);
1731    }
1732    /**
1733     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1734     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1735     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1736     * @param start the starting color as a packed float
1737     * @param end the target color as a packed float
1738     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1739     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1740     */
1741    public static float lerpFloatColors(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1742        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1743                hs = (s & 0xFF), ss = (s >>> 8) & 0xFF, ls = (s >>> 16) & 0xFF, as = s >>> 24 & 0xFE,
1744                he = (e & 0xFF), se = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, le = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
1745        float Hs = hs / 255f, Cs, Ls;
1746        if (ls == 255) {
1747            Ls = 1f;
1748            Cs = 0f;
1749        } else if (ls == 0) {
1750            Ls = 0f;
1751            Cs = 0f;
1752        } else {
1753            Ls = ls / 255f;
1754            Cs = chromaLimit(Hs, Ls) * (ss / 255f);
1755        }
1756        // Lch to Luv
1757        float Us = TrigTools.cosTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1758        float Vs = TrigTools.sinTurns(Hs) * Cs;
1759
1760        float He = he / 255f, Ce, Le;
1761        if (le == 255) {
1762            Le = 1f;
1763            Ce = 0f;
1764        } else if (le == 0) {
1765            Le = 0f;
1766            Ce = 0f;
1767        } else {
1768            Le = le / 255f;
1769            Ce = chromaLimit(He, Le) * (se / 255f);
1770        }
1771        // Lch to Luv
1772        float Ue = TrigTools.cosTurns(He) * Ce;
1773        float Ve = TrigTools.sinTurns(He) * Ce;
1774
1775        float H, S, L, U, V;
1776
1777        L = (Ls + change * (Le - Ls));
1778        U = (Us + change * (Ue - Us));
1779        V = (Vs + change * (Ve - Vs));
1780
1781        // Luv to Lch
1782        H = TrigTools.atan2Turns(V, U);
1783
1784
1785        // Lch to HSLuv
1786        if (L > 0.99999f) {
1787            return Palette.WHITE;
1788        } else if (L < 0.00001f) {
1789            return Palette.BLACK;
1790        } else {
1791            S = Math.min((float)Math.sqrt(U * U + V * V) / chromaLimit(H, L), 1);
1792        }
1793        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1794                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(H * 255.999f), 0), 255)
1795                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(S * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
1796                        | Math.min(Math.max((int)(L * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
1797                        | (((int) (as + change * (ae - as)) & 0xFE) << 24));
1798    }
1799
1800    /**
1801     * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards end by change, but keeps the alpha of start and uses the
1802     * alpha of end as an extra factor that can affect how much to change. Both start and end should be packed colors,
1803     * as from {@link #hsluv(float, float, float, float)}, and change can be between 0f (keep start) and 1f (only use
1804     * end). Both start and end must use HSLuv. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors.
1805     * @param start the starting color as a packed float; alpha will be preserved
1806     * @param end the target color as a packed float; alpha will not be used directly, and will instead be multiplied with change
1807     * @param change how much to go from start toward end, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to end
1808     * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and end
1809     */
1810    public static float lerpFloatColorsBlended(final float start, final float end, float change) {
1811        final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(end),
1812                as = s & 0xFE000000;
1813        change *= (e >>> 25) / 127f;
1814        return lerpFloatColors(start, NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(as | (e & 0xFFFFFF)), change);
1815    }
1816
1817    /**
1818     * Returns a 1:1 mix of color0 and color1. All colors should use the same color space.
1819     * This is the same as calling {@link #lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} with a change of 0.5.
1820     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1821     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1822     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1823     */
1824    public static float mix(float color0, float color1) {
1825        return lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f);
1826    }
1827
1828    /**
1829     * Returns a 1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, and color2. All colors should use the same color space.
1830     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1831     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1832     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1833     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1834     */
1835    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2) {
1836        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f);
1837    }
1838
1839    /**
1840     * Returns a 1:1:1:1 mix of color0, color1, color2, and color3. All colors should use the same color space.
1841     * @param color0 the first color to mix, as a packed float color
1842     * @param color1 the second color to mix, as a packed float color
1843     * @param color2 the third color to mix, as a packed float color
1844     * @param color3 the fourth color to mix, as a packed float color
1845     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1846     */
1847    public static float mix(float color0, float color1, float color2, float color3) {
1848        return lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(lerpFloatColors(color0, color1, 0.5f), color2, 0.33333f), color3, 0.25f);
1849    }
1850
1851    /**
1852     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1853     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1854     * @param colors an array or varargs of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1855     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1856     */
1857    public static float mix(float... colors) {
1858        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0)
1859            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1860        float result = colors[0];
1861        for (int i = 1; i < colors.length; i++) {
1862            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / (i + 1f));
1863        }
1864        return result;
1865    }
1866
1867    /**
1868     * Given several colors, this gets an even mix of all colors in equal measure.
1869     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1870     * This is mostly useful in conjunction with {@link com.badlogic.gdx.utils.FloatArray}, using its {@code items}
1871     * for colors, typically 0 for offset, and its {@code size} for size.
1872     * @param colors an array of packed float colors; all should use the same color space
1873     * @param offset the index of the first item in {@code colors} to use
1874     * @param size how many items from {@code colors} to use
1875     * @return an even mix of all colors given, as a packed float color
1876     */
1877    public static float mix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1878        final int end = offset + size;
1879        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1880            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1881        float result = colors[offset];
1882        for (int i = offset + 1, denom = 2; i < end; i++, denom++) {
1883            result = lerpFloatColors(result, colors[i], 1f / denom);
1884        }
1885        return result;
1886    }
1887
1888    /**
1889     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of varargs of alternating floats
1890     * representing colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}.
1891     * If {@code colors} is null or has no items, this returns 0f (usually transparent in most color spaces).
1892     * @param colors an array or varargs that should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1893     * @return a mix of all colors given respecting their weights, as a packed float color
1894     */
1895    public static float unevenMix(float... colors) {
1896        if(colors == null || colors.length == 0) return 0f;
1897        if(colors.length <= 2) return colors[0];
1898        return unevenMix(colors, 0, colors.length);
1899    }
1900
1901    /**
1902     * Mixes any number of colors with arbitrary weights per-color. Takes an array of alternating floats representing
1903     * colors and weights, as with {@code color, weight, color, weight...}, starting at {@code offset} in the array and
1904     * continuing for {@code size} indices in the array. The {@code size} should be an even number 2 or greater,
1905     * otherwise it will be reduced by 1. The weights can be any non-negative finite float values; this method handles
1906     * normalizing them internally.
1907     * @param colors starting at {@code offset}, this should contain alternating {@code color, weight, color, weight...} floats
1908     * @param offset where to start reading from in {@code colors}
1909     * @param size how many indices to read from {@code colors}; must be an even number
1910     * @return the mixed color, as a packed float in the same color space as the given float colors
1911     */
1912    public static float unevenMix(float[] colors, int offset, int size) {
1913        size &= -2;
1914        final int end = offset + size;
1915        if(colors == null || colors.length < end || offset < 0 || size <= 0)
1916            return 0f; // transparent, usually
1917        float result = colors[offset];
1918        float current = colors[offset + 1], total = current;
1919        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1920            total += colors[i];
1921        }
1922        total = 1f / total;
1923        current *= total;
1924        for (int i = offset+3; i < end; i += 2) {
1925            float mixColor = colors[i-1], weight = colors[i] * total;
1926            result = lerpFloatColors(result, mixColor, weight / (current += weight));
1927        }
1928        return result;
1929    }
1930
1931}
